elements.content: Three new metal−organic coordination polymers, Cd(bpdc)(phen)2·2H2O (1) (H2bpdc = biphenyl-4,4‘-dicarboxylic acid), Cd(BDC)(phen)·DMF (2) (H2BDC = benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid), and Cd2(btec)(phen)2(H2O)2 (3) (H4btec = 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid), were synthesized under different conditions by using the metal−organic coordination compound Cd(phen)2(NO3)2 as the metal source instead of inorganic metal salt. Polymer 1 is a 1-D zigzag chain, which crystallizes in the monoclinic system, Cc space group. Polymer 2 is a 2-D layered network, which crystallizes in the monoclinic system, P2/c space group. The 3-D supramolecular framework 3 crystallizes in the triclinic system, P1̄ space group. The particular interest of 3 is two entirely independent cadmium atoms in its structure. They separately form 1-D polymeric chains, which are alternately arranged to form a 3-D supramolecular framework through interchain hydrogen bonds. Additionally, these three compounds show strong fluorescence in the solid state at room temperature.

Polymer 1 is a 1-D zigzag chain, which crystallizes in the monoclinic system, Cc space group. Polymer 2 is a 2-D layered network, which crystallizes in the monoclinic system, P2/c space group. The 3-D supramolecular framework 3 crystallizes in the triclinic system, P1̄ space group. The particular interest of 3 is two entirely independent cadmium atoms in its structure. They separately form 1-D polymeric chains, which are alternately arranged to form a 3-D supramolecular framework through interchain hydrogen bonds. Additionally, these three compounds show strong fluorescence in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: Three new coordination polymers, 1-D chainlike, 2-D layered, and 3-D supramolecular networks, were synthesized by using the metal−organic coordination compound Cd(phen)2(NO3)2 as the metal source instead of inorganic metal salt under different conditions. These three compounds exhibit good thermal stability and fluorescent properties.

elements.content: Metal−organic polymeric frameworks have attracted much more attention in the past decade, owing to their various intriguing molecular topologies and crystal packing motifs along with potential applications as functional materials. A fertile ground for the design of single-crystalline solids has been provided by metal−organic coordination polymers, and many efforts have been made to the rational design of functional metal−organic crystalline materials. Lately, it is demonstrated that a similar (or better) performance in sorption and catalysis than commonly used zeolites (ZSM-5, X, Y) can be obtained if 1-D metal−organic complexes are used as precursors to prepare metal−organic frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic polymeric frameworks have attracted much more attention in the past decade, owing to their various intriguing molecular topologies and crystal packing motifs along with potential applications as functional materials. A fertile ground for the design of single-crystalline solids has been provided by metal-organic coordination polymers, and many efforts have been made to the rational design of functional metal-organic crystalline materials. Lately, it is demonstrated that a similar (or better) performance in sorption and catalysis than commonly used zeolites (ZSM-5, X, Y) can be obtained if 1-D metal-organic complexes are used as precursors to prepare metal-organic frameworks.

elements.content: Various metal−organic coordination frameworks were constructed from inorganic metal salt and bi- and tetracarboxylate ligands. Here we replace inorganic metal salt by a metal−organic coordination compound as the metal source. Metal−organic coordination compounds provide not only metal ions but also segmental organic ligands in the synthesis system. Hence, novel topologies and particularly chemical and physical properties may be obtained. Our recent efforts in using metal−organic coordination compounds as the metal source to construct metal−organic polymeric frameworks have led to two novel supramolecular polymeric frameworks with intriguing topologies and fluorescent properties. In this paper, we report three new fluorescent polymeric frameworks, Cd(bpdc)(phen)2·2H2O (1), Cd(BDC)(phen)·DMF (2), and Cd2(btec)(phen)2(H2O)2 (3), which are constructed from the metal−organic coordination compound Cd(phen)2(NO3)2 with biphenyl-4,4‘-dicarboxylic acid, benzenc-1,4-dicarboxylic acid, and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic anhydride, respectively, under different synthetic conditions. Herein, we describe the synthesis, the crystal structure, the thermal stability, and the fluorescence properties of them.

Our recent efforts in using metal-organic coordination compounds as the metal source to construct metal-organic polymeric frameworks have led to two novel supramolecular polymeric frameworks with intriguing topologies and fluorescent properties. In this paper, we report three new fluorescent polymeric frameworks, Cd(bpdc)(phen)2⋅2H2O (1), Cd(BDC)(phen)⋅DMF (2), and Cd2(btec)(phen)2(H2O)2 (3), which are constructed from the metal-organic coordination compound Cd(phen)2(NO3)2 with biphenyl-4,4‘-dicarboxylic acid, benzenc-1,4-dicarboxylic acid, and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic anhydride, respectively, under different synthetic conditions. Herein, we describe the synthesis, the crystal structure, the thermal stability, and the fluorescence properties of them.

elements.content: General Remarks. The elemental analysis was performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 element analyzer and inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis on a Perkin-Elmer Optima 3300DV ICP spectrometer. The IR spectrum was obtained on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer. Thermogravimetirc analysis was performed on a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 unit in air and at 1 atm pressure at a heating rate of 5 °C min-1. Fluorescence spectra were performed on a LS 55 fluorescence/phosphorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General Remarks. The elemental analysis was performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 element analyzer and inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis on a Perkin-Elmer Optima 3300DV ICP spectrometer. The IR spectrum was obtained on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer. Thermogravimetirc analysis was performed on a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 unit in air and at 1 atm pressure at a heating rate of 5 °C min-1. Fluorescence spectra were performed on a LS 55 fluorescence/phosphorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature.

elements.content: Preparation. Compound 1. Synthesis under hydrothermal conditions. A mixture of Cd(phen)2(NO3)2 (0.158 g, 0.25 mmol), H2bpdc (0.061 g, 0.25 mmol), NaOH (0.020 g, 0.50 mmol), and 10.0 mL of distilled water was stirred fully in air, and then sealed in a 23-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, which was heated at 180 °C for 4 days. After the sample was cooled to room temperature, colorless block crystals were produced in 41% yield (0.077 g). C38H28N4O6Cd1 (749.04):  calcd. C, 60.93%; H, 3.77%; N, 7.48%; found C, 61.04%; H, 3.69%; N, 7.39%. IR(KBr):  ν = 3419, 3056, 1598, 1538, 1429, 1373, 1094, 856, 730 cm-1.

elements.content: Compound 2. Preparation under solvothermal conditions by reaction of Cd(phen)2(NO3)2 (0.179 g, 0.30 mmol), H2BDC (0.025 g, 0.15 mmol) in a solution of N,N‘-dimethylformamide (DMF) (3.0 mL), absolute ethanol (3.0 mL), and distilled water (3.0 mL) at 140 °C for 2 days produced large yellow block crystals in 56% yield (0.089 g). C23H19N3O5Cd1(529.81):  caldc. C, 52.14%; H, 3.61%; N, 7.93%; found C, 52.02%; H, 3.65%; N, 7.88%. IR(KBr):  ν = 3047, 2932, 1702, 1573, 1384, 1147, 1083, 850, 728 cm-1.

elements.content: Compound 3. Colorless flake crystals were filtered off, washed with absolute ethanol, and dried at room temperature. The yield was about 64%. (0.139 g) C34H22N4O10Cd2 (871.36):  caldc. Synthesis. Polymer 1 was synthesized under hydrothermal conditions and its formation was strongly influenced by reaction conditions such as pH value and temperature. Inorganic hydroxide NaOH was introduced to deprotonate carboxylic acid and the reaction was performed at 180 °C to improve the solubility of H2bpdc in water. Polymer 2 was obtained under solvothermal conditions similar to previously reported examples including H2BDC ligand. The synthesis of 3 was performed under mild conditions in mixed solution, which was different from other polymeric complexes hydrothermally constructed from 1,2,4,5-benzenctetra carboxylic acid.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Synthesis. Polymer 1 was synthesized under hydrothermal conditions and its formation was strongly influenced by reaction conditions such as pH value and temperature. Inorganic hydroxide NaOH was introduced to deprotonate carboxylic acid and the reaction was performed at 180 °C to improve the solubility of H2bpdc in water. Polymer 2 was obtained under solvothermal conditions similar to previously reported examples including H2BDC ligand. The synthesis of 3 was performed under mild conditions in mixed solution, which was different from other polymeric complexes hydrothermally constructed from 1,2,4,5-benzenctetra carboxylic acid.

elements.content: Description of Crystal Structure. Cd(bpdc)(phen) 2 · 2H 2 O (1). A single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that 1 is a 1-D zigzag polymeric coordination chain. In the building unit of 1, the cadmium center adopts a distorted octahedral geometry by coordinating to four nitrogen atoms (N1, N2, N3, N4) of two chelating phen ligands and two oxygen atoms (O1, O3) of two monodentate carboxylate groups from two bpdc ligands. (Figure a) The bond lengths and angles of Cd−Ocar are similar to those in other cadmium−carboxylate coordination polymers. Each bpdc ligand bridges two cadmium atoms in bis-monodentate fashion to form a 1-D infinite zigzag chain as shown in Figure b. The structure of 1 is different from that of molecular rhombi [Cu2(bpa)2(phen)2(H2O)2]·2H2O, although they are constructed from the same organic ligands. For [Cu2(bpa)2(phen)2(H2O)2]·2H2O, each copper center chelates to one phen ligand, while cadmium atom in 1 chelates to two phen ligands, although there is steric hindrance to a certain extent, which might be due to phen ligands coming from metal source Cd(phen)2(NO3)2.

(Figure a) The bond lengths and angles of Cd-Ocar are similar to those in other cadmium-carboxylate  coordination polymers. elements.content: Cd(BDC)(phen) · DMF (2). X-ray crystallography reveals that 2 is a 2-D layered network. There are one Cd atom, one BDC ligand, one phen ligand, and one free DMF molecule in the building unit. The cadmium atom adopts a seven-coordinate structure by coordinating to two nitrogen atoms (N1, N2) of one chelating phen ligand and five oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3A, O4, O3) of carboxylate groups of two different BDC ligands. (Figure a) For 2, the BDC ligand has two coordination fashions. In one fashion, the ligand contains two chelating bidentate carboxylate groups (Chart a), while in the other the ligand contains two chelating/bridging bis-bidentate carboxylate groups (Chart b). The Cd2(CO2)4 clusters are linked by four BDC ligands, two of which adopt the first coordination fashion (Chart a) and the other two adopt the second coordination fashion (Chart b), to lead to an undulating 2-D layered network along the ac plane (Figure b). Free DMF molecule locates between adjacent undulating layers, as shown in Figure c. Interestingly, the structure of the 2-D layered network 2 is significantly different from that of Cd(BDC)(phen)(H2O)15 in our previous work, although they are both constructed from Cd(phen)2(NO3)2 and H2BDC ligands. For Cd(BDC)(phen)(H2O), there are two terminal groups in the structure, phen ligand and coordinated H2O molecule, which result in the structure only extending along one direction and finally forming a 1-D chain. But for 2, there are only one phen ligand as terminal group and a BDC ligand adopting a chelating/bridging bis-bidentate coordination structure (Chart b), which results in the structure extending along two directions and ultimately forming a 2-D layered network.

elements.content: Cd 2 (btec)(phen) 2 (H 2 O) 2 (3). A single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that 3 consists of two different one-dimensional chains in which btec ligands adopt different coordination modes. There are two independent cadmium atoms, five-coordinate Cd1 and six-coordinate Cd2, in each asymmetric unit of 3. Cd1 and Cd2 separately form 1-D polymeric chains, which are alternately arranged along the b axis in the structure.

elements.content: Cd2 adopts a distorted octahedral geometry by coordinating to two nitrogen atoms (N3, N4) of one chelating phen ligands and four oxygen atoms (O7, O8, O9, O6) of one chelating carboxylate group, one monodentate carboxylate group from one btec ligand (Chart b), and one coordinated H2O molecule (Figure a). Each btec ligand in the coordination fashion, as shown in Chart b, links four crystallographically equivalent Cd2 atoms to lead to a broad zonal 1-D chain along the a axis (Figure b).

elements.content: Each broad zonal 1-D chain constructed from Cd1 can form C−H···O hydrogen bonds with an adjacent 1-D chain. C5 with H5 forms C5−H5···O3 (3.483 Å, 153.79°)19 hydrogen bonds with carboxylate O3 of btec ligands from adjacent polymeric chains to lead to undulating layered networks [Cd1(btec)0.5(phen)(H2O)] n along the ac plane (Figure ). While each broad zonal 1-D chain constructed from Cd2 can also form C−H···O hydrogen bonds with neighboring 1-D chains. C20 with H20 and C22 with H22 form C20−H20···O10 (3.291 Å, 137.66°)19 and C22−H22···O7 (3.226 Å, 150.91°)19 hydrogen bonds with carboxylate O10 and O7 of btec ligands from neighboring chains, respectively, to lead to planar layered networks [Cd2(btec)0.5(phen)(H2O)] n along the ac plane (Figure ).

elements.content: Undulating layered networks constructed from Cd1 and planar layered networks constructed from Cd2 alternately arrange in order along the b axis (Figure ). Coordinated H2O molecules of two kinds of layered networks are pointed out and well positioned to form O···O hydrogen bonds with carboxylate oxygen atoms. The oxygen atoms (O5) of coordinated H2O molecules from 2-D undulating layers constructed from Cd1 form strong hydrogen bonds (O5···O7:  2.729 Å) with carboxylate oxygen atoms (O7) of btec ligands from neighboring 2-D planar layers constructed from Cd2. At the same time, the oxygen atoms (O6) of coordinated H2O molecules from 2-D planar layers constructed from Cd2 form strong hydrogen bonds (O6···O2:  2.727 Å, O6···O4:  2.864 Å) with carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2, O4) of btec ligands from neighboring undulating 2-D layers constructed from Cd1. There are also C−H···O hydrogen bonds (C9−H9···O10:  3.461 Å, 164.10°; C26−H26···O3:  3.376 Å, 151.15°)19 between neighboring different 2-D layers. Thus, O···O hydrogen bonds along with C−H···O hydrogen bonds further extend 2-D layered networks into a 3-D supramolecular framework along the [010] direction.

elements.content: Metal ions and organic ligands especially carboxylate ligands tend to form clusters in the formation of polymers. Two, three, four, and eight core clusters, and even 15 core clusters have been found in polymers. But two entirely independent metal−organic clusters exist in one polymer such as 3, which was infrequent. A one core cluster and a two core cluster independently exist in one polymer, which was found in Cd2(HBTC)2(phen)2·nCd(HBTC)(phen)2 in our previous work. The formation of independent clusters in one polymer might be due to a metal−organic coordination compound instead of an inorganic metal salt as the metal resource in the synthesis system and the lower synthesis temperature resulting in low symmetry (P1̄ space group) from the viewpoint of entropy.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric Analysis. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed to gauge the thermal stability of these compounds. For 1, there are three separate weight loss steps. The first weight loss of 4.9% occurs at about 100 °C, which is attributed to the evacuation of two free H2O molecules (calcd. 4.8%). The second weight loss of 24.5% at about 300 °C corresponds to the loss of one coordinated phen ligand (calcd. 24.1%). The third two-step weight loss of 53.3% between 400−510 °C corresponds to coordinated phen and bpdc ligands. The remaining weight of 17.3% corresponds to the percentage (17.1%) of the Cd and O components, indicating that the final product is CdO. TGA curve of 1 indicates that the 1-D chain formulated as Cd(bpdc)(phen)2 is stable below 300 °C. Interestingly, a phase formulated as Cd(bpdc)(phen) is also stable in the temperature range of 300−400 °C, even after one coordinated phen ligand is removed. For 2, there are two well-separated weight loss steps. A weight loss of 14.0% occurs at about 140 °C, corresponding to the removal of one free DMF molecule (calcd. 13.8%). The following two-step weight loss of 62.1% between 400−550 °C corresponds to coordinated phen and BDC ligands. The remaining weight of 23.9% corresponds to the final product CdO (calcd. 24.2%). TGA of 2 showed the 2-D network Cd(BDC)(phen) does not decompose and is stable below 400 °C. For 3, there are also two well-separated weight loss steps. A weight loss of 4.2% at about 150 °C is for the removal of two coordinated H2O molecules (4.1%). The following weight loss of 66.2% between 400−570 °C corresponds to coordinated phen and btec ligands. The remaining weight of 29.6% corresponds to the percentage (29.5%) of the final product 2CdO. The result of TGA of 3 showed the structure is still stable below 400 °C even after the coordinated H2O molecules are removed. TGA results of these compounds shows that they are stable below 400 °C, unusually high for coordination polymers, which indicates their good thermal stability.

elements.content: Fluorescent Properties. Solid-state 1, 2, and 3 exhibit strong fluorescence at room temperature. The reactant Cd(phen)2(NO3)2 also fluoresces in the solid state. The emission bands for Cd(phen)2(NO3)2 can be assigned to the intraligand fluorescent emission of coordinated phen ligands (Figure a). For the multiple emission bands for 1 (Figure b) and 2 (Figure c), the main peaks locate at the same position, compared with those of Cd(phen)2(NO3)2. As very weak fluorescent emission results from π* → n transition of carboxylate ligands (H2bpdc and H2BDC) compared with that of π* → π transition of phen or/and fluorescence quenching resulting from the carboxy group of carboxylate ligands (which are strong electron withdrawing groups), carboxylate ligands almost have no contribution to the fluorescent emission, although free H2bpdc and free H2BDC show fluorescent emission in the solid state. So multiple emission bands for 1 and 2 can be assigned to π* → π transition of coordinated phen ligands. And the multiple emission bands of 2 are different from those of Cd(BDC)(phen)(H2O), which may be due to the significant difference of their topological structure. A single emission band for 3, although obviously different from multibands of 1 and 2, still might be attributed to intraligand charge transfer of coordinated phen ligands (Figure d). Here H4btec ligands have also no attribution to fluorescent emission of 3 like that of 1 and 2. The large difference is mainly due to the complicated structure of 3, with linkage of alternately arranged different 1-D chains through interchain hydrogen bonds, in which btec ligands adopt different coordination fashions. The single broad emission band might result from multiple charge-transfer with close transition energies caused by the complicated structure 3, which is somewhat similar to that of Cd2(HBTC)2(phen)2·nCd(HBTC)(phen)2.

elements.content: Three fluorescent polymeric frameworks in different dimensions have been synthesized by using a metal−organic coordination compound as the metal source under different synthetic conditions. Notably for 3, two entirely independent cadmium atoms exist in its structure. They separately form 1-D polymeric chains, which are alternately arranged. It is the interchain hydrogen bonds between alternately arranged different polymeric chains that extend the 1-D broad zonal chains into a 3-D supramolecular framework, in contrast to those supramolecular structures constructed from the same polymeric chains through hydrogen bonds. These three compounds show good thermal stability and fluorescent properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Three fluorescent polymeric frameworks in different dimensions have been synthesized by using a metal-organic coordination compound as the metal source under different synthetic conditions. Notably for 3, two entirely independent cadmium atoms exist in its structure. They separately form 1-D polymeric chains, which are alternately arranged. It is the interchain hydrogen bonds between alternately arranged different polymeric chains that extend the 1-D broad zonal chains into a 3-D supramolecular framework, in contrast to those supramolecular structures constructed from the same polymeric chains through hydrogen bonds. These three compounds show good thermal stability and fluorescent properties.

cln_elements.content:
Preparation. Compound 1. Synthesis under hydrothermal conditions. A mixture of Cd(phen)2(NO3)2 (0.158 g, 0.25 mmol), H2bpdc (0.061 g, 0.25 mmol), NaOH (0.020 g, 0.50 mmol), and 10.0 mL of distilled water was stirred fully in air, and then sealed in a 23-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, which was heated at 180 °C for 4 days. After the sample was cooled to room temperature, colorless block crystals were produced in 41% yield (0.077 g). C38H28N4O6Cd1 (749.04):  calcd. C, 60.93%; H, 3.77%; N, 7.48%; found C, 61.04%; H, 3.69%; N, 7.39%. IR(KBr):  ν = 3419, 3056, 1598, 1538, 1429, 1373, 1094, 856, 730 cm-1.

Compound 2. Preparation under solvothermal conditions by reaction of Cd(phen)2(NO3)2 (0.179 g, 0.30 mmol), H2BDC (0.025 g, 0.15 mmol) in a solution of N,N‘-dimethylformamide (DMF) (3.0 mL), absolute ethanol (3.0 mL), and distilled water (3.0 mL) at 140 °C for 2 days produced large yellow block crystals in 56% yield (0.089 g). C23H19N3O5Cd1(529.81):  caldc. C, 52.14%; H, 3.61%; N, 7.93%; found C, 52.02%; H, 3.65%; N, 7.88%. IR(KBr):  ν = 3047, 2932, 1702, 1573, 1384, 1147, 1083, 850, 728 cm-1.

Compound 3. Synthesis by allowing Cd(phen)2(NO3)2 (0.158 g, 0.25 mmol), 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic anhydride (0.055 g, 0.25 mmol) to react in a solution of N,N‘-dimethylformamide (DMF) (10.0 mL), absolute ethanol (2.0 mL), and distilled water (3.0 mL) at 55 °C for 6 days. Colorless flake crystals were filtered off, washed with absolute ethanol, and dried at room temperature. The yield was about 64%. (0.139 g) C34H22N4O10Cd2 (871.36):  caldc. C, 46.87%; H, 2.54%; N, 6.43%; found C, 47.02%; H, 2.48%; N, 6.36%. IR(KBr):  ν = 3378, 3059, 1558, 1378, 1134, 1083, 858, 728 cm-1.
